shortDescriptions.value: Sunday Morning

titles.value: Breaking down Trump's tariff strategy and how the stock markets are preparing

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump is promising big tariffs on what he is calling "Liberation Day" but has stipulated that the moves may be "kinder" than what other countries are imposing on the U.S. This comes as the markets react in real-time to the uncertainty over potential global trade wars. CBS News' Jennifer Jacobs and Kelly O'Grady report.

titles.value: Why the Wisconsin, Florida elections matter to the Trump administration

shortDescriptions.value: In Wisconsin, voters will elect a new supreme court justice that may involved in pivotal state cases moving forward. This comes as two districts in Florida hold special elections that may affect the balance of power in the House of Representatives. CBS News' Ed O'Keefe and CBS News Miami's Jim DeFede have more.

titles.value: Cory Booker has been protesting Trump policies on Senate floor for 16 hours

shortDescriptions.value: Democratic New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker has been protesting President Trump's policies on the Senate floor in a marathon speech that has lasted more than 16 hours. CBS News' Nikole Killion reports.

titles.value: Behind the "administrative error" that led to a man's deportation to El Salvador

shortDescriptions.value: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, who had protected status in the U.S., was deported to El Salvador's CECOT mega-prison after an apparent "administrative error," according to acting Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office director Robert Cerna. CBS News' Katrina Kaufman reports.

titles.value: Canada braces for Trump's new tariffs

shortDescriptions.value: Canadians are bracing for President Trump's highly-anticipated "Liberation Day" tariffs that could increase the chances of a long-lasting trade war between the allied nations. Mercedes Stephenson, Global News' Ottawa bureau chief, joins CBS News with more.

titles.value: Deadly severe storm tore through school roof and injured students

shortDescriptions.value: A severe storm system that passed through Dothan, Alabama, injured students after it ripped parts of a school's roof off. This comes as reports of fatalities emerge from the weather event that slammed the U.S. CBS News' Skyler Henry reports.

titles.value: Trump immigration policies that are in court limbo

shortDescriptions.value: Several Trump administration immigration policies remain in limbo as they work their way through the courts. CBS News legal contributor Caroline Polisi has more on the Temporary Protected Status (TPS) case and the case surrounding deportation flights to El Salvador.

titles.value: Magician David Kwong brings on how to bring fun mischief to April Fools' Day

shortDescriptions.value: Magician and puzzle master David Kwong joins "CBS Mornings Plus" to talk about his new children's book, "How to Fool Your Parents," which teaches over two dozen magic tricks, just in time for April Fools' Day.

titles.value: DOJ seeking death penalty in Luigi Mangione case, Bondi says

shortDescriptions.value: Attorney General Pam Bondi says the Department of Justice will seek the death penalty in the case against Luigi Mangione for the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson in New York City. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul reports.

titles.value: Trump's team has been presenting plans for potential tariffs as announcement looms

shortDescriptions.value: The White House said members of President Trump's trade team have been presenting options for potential tariffs as an announcement nears. CBS News' Natalie Brand reports.

titles.value: How to tell if an image is fake content from AI

shortDescriptions.value: Artificial intelligence is producing images that seem real and could fool people seeking verified information. CBS News Confirmed's Kara Fellows breaks down how to verify images online.

titles.value: How Butch Wilmore, Suni Williams describe their long stay in space

shortDescriptions.value: Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are sharing more details about their experience in space aboard the International Space Station after their time in Boeing's Starliner capsule. CBS News' Mark Strassmann spoke to the pair about their journey.

titles.value: How news outlets used to celebrate April Fools' Day

shortDescriptions.value: From "spaghetti trees" to robot anchors, April Fools pranks once lit up newsrooms. Historian Kenneth C. Davis joins "CBS Mornings Plus" to reflect on how the tradition changed with rising concerns over misinformation.

titles.value: Cory Booker spent all night delivering a marathon speech to protest Trump policies

shortDescriptions.value: Sen. Cory Booker, a Democrat from New Jersey, held an overnight marathon speech on the Senate floor to protest President Trump's policies. CBS News' Nikole Killion reports.

titles.value: Exclusive discounts from CBS Mornings Deals

shortDescriptions.value: On this edition of CBS Mornings Deals, we show you items that might just become essentials in your everyday life. Visit cbsdeals.com to take advantage of these exclusive deals today. CBS earns commissions on purchases made through cbsdeals.com.

titles.value: Reporter's Notebook: Telling the whole truth about America's history

shortDescriptions.value: Last week, President Trump signed an executive order calling for "sanity and truth" in American history, directing the Smithsonian and national landmarks to present it in a favorable light. Can history be simultaneously sane, true, and positive? "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson gives his take.

titles.value: The dangers of unbridled artificial intelligence

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump has vowed to remove barriers stopping America from being the leader in artificial intelligence development. Christopher DiCarlo, author of "Building a God: The Ethics of Artificial Intelligence and the Race to Control It," joins to discuss why he's alarmed by the prospect of AI with no guardrails.

titles.value: Georgia family fights to keep their land in eminent domain dispute

shortDescriptions.value: What price would you put on a family legacy? In some circumstances, there's not even a price affixed; it's simply taken through eminent domain. Skyler Henry reports on one family's yearslong fight to preserve not just land but history.

titles.value: Desperate search for survivors buried in rubble after Myanmar earthquake

shortDescriptions.value: The death toll from a powerful earthquake in southeast Asia last week has topped more than 2,000 victims. More international search and rescue teams are now on the scene. Anna Coren reports on the desperate search for survivors.

titles.value: Starliner astronauts on returning home, outlook and more

shortDescriptions.value: Millions of people followed how astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams' eight-day mission to the International Space Station became a nine-month space saga. Now they're home in Houston and talking to Mark Strassmann.

titles.value: What to expect in Trump's tariff announcement

shortDescriptions.value: The Trump administration is planning to impose a round of fresh tariffs on April 2, a day President Trump has dubbed "Liberation Day." Kelly O'Grady explains what's at stake.

titles.value: The new baseball bat taking MLB by storm

shortDescriptions.value: The torpedo bat is the talk of baseball after the New York Yankees used it to sink the Milwaukee Brewers, 20-9. Dave Malkoff has the story behind the bombers' not-so-secret weapon.

titles.value: North Carolina radio station becomes voice of recovery after Hurricane Helene

shortDescriptions.value: After Hurricane Helene devastated western North Carolina, a couple of radio broadcasters played a critical role in keeping residents informed. Now, six months later, they have taken on a new role in the recovery. Skyler Henry reports.

titles.value: Why billionaires are pumping millions into Wisconsin Supreme Court race

shortDescriptions.value: Voters in Wisconsin will be heading to the polls to elect a justice to the highest state court. Billionaires on both sides are pumping in money. Ed O'Keefe has more.

titles.value: Many Americans concerned Trump's reciprocal tariffs will raise prices

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump is set to announce the next round of tariffs on Wednesday. Many Americans feel he's focusing too much on these taxes, which will raise the cost of imported goods, and not enough on inflation. Nancy Cordes and Lana Zak report.

titles.value: Nearly 1 in 4 close calls involve military aircraft, data shows

shortDescriptions.value: Nearly 1 in 4 of the more than 8,000 near midair collisions voluntarily reported to the FAA between 1987 and 2021 involve at least one military aircraft, according to a CBS News data analysis. Kris Van Cleave has more.

titles.value: 3/31: CBS Evening News

shortDescriptions.value: Nearly 1 in 4 close calls involve military aircraft, data shows; The new baseball bat taking the MLB by storm

titles.value: Where the economy is headed amid inflation worries and tariff impact

shortDescriptions.value: Wall Street's decline fueled by inflation worries and the impact of tariffs likely won't be short-lived as wider reciprocal import taxes are set to go into effect next week. Consumer confidence along with spending aren't faring much better. Jo Ling Kent joins to discuss.

titles.value: Many drivers forced to abandon vehicles amid heavy flooding in South Texas

shortDescriptions.value: At least three people are dead in South Texas following a severe storm that delivered more than a foot of rain. That's about half the precipitation the region typically sees in an entire year. Karen Hua reports.

titles.value: Researcher says Long COVID causing "great deal of suffering"

shortDescriptions.value: The pandemic may be over, but millions are still dealing with COVID-19's effects. The CDC estimates nearly 20 million Americans are struggling with the effects of Long COVID --the persistence of ongoing health problems long after the infection has passed. Bradley Blackburn has more.

titles.value: With 8 No. 1 hits, Jordan Davis returns with new music and a big surprise

shortDescriptions.value: Jordan Davis, the country star behind eight No. 1 hits, joins "CBS Mornings Plus" to share a first look at his latest single and reveal a big announcement following recent CMA and ACM wins.

titles.value: Author Gretchen Rubin on how to find order, calm, and joy in everyday life

shortDescriptions.value: Bestselling author Gretchen Rubin joins "CBS Mornings Plus" to discuss her new book "Secrets of Adulthood," offering practical insights on happiness, calm, and finding meaning in everyday life.

titles.value: How Wisconsin's high court race became the most expensive in U.S. history

shortDescriptions.value: Common Cause Wisconsin's Jay Heck joins to explain how the state's nonpartisan judicial race became the most expensive in U.S. history, with more than $80 million spent and growing concerns about outside influence.

titles.value: Jay Ellis on how new film "Freaky Tales" blends sports, action, and revenge

shortDescriptions.value: Jay Ellis, star of "Insecure" and "Top Gun: Maverick" takes on a fictional version of Warriors star Sleepy Floyd in "Freaky Tales," a genre-blending film set in 1987 Oakland that reimagines the night Floyd scored 29 points in one quarter and what happens when he becomes the target of a heist.

titles.value: Casting director Tess Sanchez reflects on life after Hollywood in new book

shortDescriptions.value: Tess Sanchez helped launch the careers of stars like Melissa McCarthy and Jamie Foxx. Now, she's turning the page with a collection of essays about motherhood, identity, and being laid off from the industry she once helped shape.

titles.value: 2 Florida sisters deliver hope and healing with handmade dolls for hurricane survivors

shortDescriptions.value: As part of CBS News' "Surprise Cities" series, CBS News contributor David Begnaud visits Greenville, South Carolina, where he meets Kenzie and Kayleigh, two young girls delivering customized American Girl dolls to children affected by Hurricane Helene. Their mission of compassion is helping other kids heal through play.

titles.value: Exclusive discounts from CBS Mornings Deals

shortDescriptions.value: On this edition of CBS Mornings Deals, we show you items that might just become essentials in your everyday life. Visit cbsdeals.com to take advantage of these exclusive deals today. CBS earns commissions on purchases made through cbsdeals.com.

titles.value: FAA investigating more incidents at Washington's Reagan National Airport

shortDescriptions.value: The FAA is investigating more aviation incidents at Washington's Reagan National Airport. On Friday, a military jet got close enough to a departing Delta flight that it set off an alarm in the cockpit. On Saturday, a United flight had a close encounter with a kite. CBS News senior transportation correspondent Kris Van Cleave has more.

titles.value: Texas mother of twins describes efforts to protect infants amid growing measles outbreak

shortDescriptions.value: Davery Jaso's infant twins were born in West Texas in the middle of the state's worst measles outbreak in decades. She describes efforts to protect her children, who like millions of others, are too young to be vaccinated.

titles.value: Prince Harry faces bullying accusation after leaving charity

shortDescriptions.value: Prince Harry resigned last week from the charity he co-founded, Sentebale, citing a breakdown in the relationship between the organization's board and chair, Dr. Sophie Chandauka. In an interview with Sky News, Chandauka said she experienced harassment and bullying on the board.

titles.value: Freed Israeli hostages call for end to war, to bring remaining Gaza hostages home

shortDescriptions.value: Freed hostages are among those calling for a new Israel-Hamas ceasefire. They warn renewed bombing in Gaza jeopardizes the lives of the 24 remaining captives, who are believed to be alive.

titles.value: 60 Minutes reports on the bourbon barrel business

shortDescriptions.value: Next week, 60 Minutes will explore the fascinating life of the bourbon barrel. New oak barrels are built, charred, then filled with what will become bourbon through years of aging.

titles.value: What Trump's silencing of Voice of America means for listeners worldwide | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: Voice of America is silent after President Trump effectively shut down the broadcaster. VOA journalists are speaking out about what this could mean for an audience of 360 million around the world.

titles.value: California wildfires left behind 9 billion pounds of toxic ash and debris | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: After the wildfires ravaged homes in Los Angeles, California, cleanup crews faced a new challenge: electric car batteries that can explode when damaged.

titles.value: 3/30/2025: Hostages; Voice of America; Left Behind

shortDescriptions.value: First, freed Israeli hostage Yarden Bibas speaks out. Then, a report on what Trump's silencing of Voice of America means for listeners worldwide. And, a look at California wildfires cleanup challenges.

titles.value: Radio Free Europe sues over U.S. funding cuts | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: Radio Free Europe, which has been a vital tool in the fight against disinformation and authoritarianism, filed a lawsuit after President Trump moved to cut funding to U.S. government-run broadcasters.

titles.value: George Clooney: The 2025 60 Minutes Interview

shortDescriptions.value: George Clooney is making his Broadway debut in "Good Night, and Good Luck," telling the story of pioneering reporter Edward R. Murrow. During rehearsals, Clooney stressed the importance of a free press.

titles.value: Cartel smugglers at U.S.-Canada border advertise to migrants on TikTok | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: Migrants, some with help from smugglers found on TikTok, are crossing the U.S.-Canada border. A Sinaloa cartel member says President Trump's illegal immigration crackdown will not stop the smuggling.

titles.value: A dad's mission to uncover brain injuries after Navy SEAL son's suicide | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: A veteran's brain showed no signs of physical injury, until a post-mortem after his suicide found microscopic scars. Now, his father is fighting to protect others in the military.

titles.value: 3/23/2025: Death on the Chazy River; Larkin's War; Mr. Clooney Goes to Broadway

shortDescriptions.value: First, a look at how some migrants cross into the U.S. from Canada. Then, a report on a dad's mission to uncover brain injuries after his Navy SEAL son's suicide. And, George Clooney: The 2025 60 Minutes Interview.

titles.value: 3/16/2025: Under the Radar; Americas Own; Werner Herzog

shortDescriptions.value: First, an investigation into U.S. drone swarm mysteries dating back years. Then, a report on DEI and a cancelled U.S. Marine Band concert. And, Werner Herzog: The 60 Minutes Interview.

titles.value: U.S. Marine Band forced to cancel concert with students of color after Trump DEI order

shortDescriptions.value: After an executive order ending DEI initiatives, the U.S. Marine Band canceled a concert featuring young musicians of color. Veterans stepped in to mentor the aspiring musicians.

titles.value: Drones flying around the Northeast last year weren't the first swarm | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: Drones have repeatedly swarmed sensitive military sites. Current and former Air Force generals, along with a senior member of Congress, say the incursions pose a security threat.

titles.value: Changes at the Social Security Administration | 60 Minutes

shortDescriptions.value: After a 2023 60 Minutes report, Social Security said it would claw back no more than 10% of a persons monthly check to recover an overpayment. That changed earlier this month under President Trump.

titles.value: Werner Herzog: The 60 Minutes Interview

shortDescriptions.value: Werner Herzog had never even seen a movie until he was 11. Now 82, the visionary director is working constantly, still making movies no one else would or could ever dream of.

titles.value: "Dead Girls Don't Talk"

shortDescriptions.value: A man charged with murder for poisoning two women tells a friend, "dead girls don't talk." Brave survivors speak out on their behalf. "48 Hours" contributor Jonathan Vigliotti reports.

titles.value: The Puzzling Death of Susann Sills

shortDescriptions.value: The wife of a fertility doctor is found dead at the bottom of a staircase. Did her dogs play a role in her death or was the scene staged to cover a murder? "48 Hours" correspondent Tracy Smith reports.

titles.value: Could Angela Prichard Have Been Saved?

shortDescriptions.value: A woman repeatedly called police for help when she was attacked, stalked, and intimidated by her husband. It didn't stop him from killing her. "48 Hours" contributor Jonathan Vigliotti reports.

titles.value: The Unending Search for Sara Anne Wood

shortDescriptions.value: Investigators are locked in a 30-year game of cat and mouse with a child serial killer to find the body of 12-year-old Sara. "48 Hours" correspondent Erin Moriarty reports.

titles.value: Cati Blauvelt: Death of a Soldiers Wife

shortDescriptions.value: A soldier goes on the run after his wife is murdered.  With him, his 17-year-old girlfriend.  What does she know? "48 Hours" correspondent Peter Van Sant reports.

titles.value: The Assassination of Jeff German

shortDescriptions.value: A Las Vegas journalist is stabbed to death while investigating claims a boss was toxic. Did his reporting make him a target? "48 Hours" correspondent Peter Van Sant reports.

titles.value: The Hit-and-Run Homicide of Davis McClendon

shortDescriptions.value: A romance is cut short when a man is found dead near his mangled car. His newfound love is convinced it was no accident. "48 Hours" correspondent Anne-Marie Green reports.

titles.value: The People v. Kouri Richins

shortDescriptions.value: When her husband is found dead of an apparent overdose, Kouri Richins writes a children's book about grief. Soon after shes charged with his murder. "48 Hours" contributor Natalie Morales reports.

titles.value: Justine's Voice

shortDescriptions.value: After a teenager is strangled and buried alive, her family takes on the fight to keep her convicted killers behind bars. Were her voice says Justines sister. "48 Hours" contributor Natalie Morales reports.

titles.value: Justice for Amie Harwick

shortDescriptions.value: Amie Harwick's roommate speaks out about trying to save her and helping to convict her killer. "48 Hours" correspondent Erin Moriarty reports.

titles.value: It's About Danni

shortDescriptions.value: When 15-year-old Danni Houchins is found dead in a swamp, her family says they were led to believe she drowned.  24 years later, Dannis sister learns the terrible truth. "48 Hours" correspondent Peter Van Sant reports.

titles.value: Kristen Trickle: Autopsy of the Mind

shortDescriptions.value: A Kansas woman is found dying from a gunshot wound. Evidence at the scene doesnt add up, so a prosecutor gets creative. "48 Hours" correspondent Erin Moriarty reports.

titles.value: The No Body Case of Dee Warner

shortDescriptions.value: When a woman disappears, her children are certain shes been murdered. But without a body, they know it will be hard to get justice. "48 Hours" correspondent Erin Moriarty reports.

titles.value: Death by Eye Drops

shortDescriptions.value: A caregiver is accused of poisoning her friend with eye drops. She says investigators got it wrong. "48 Hours" contributor Jericka Duncan reports.

titles.value: The Ivy League Murder

shortDescriptions.value: A newly engaged Yale graduate student is gunned down by an unknown attacker after a fender bender. Was it extreme road rage or was he targeted? "48 Hours" correspondent Anne-Marie Green reports.

titles.value: The Price of Milk: Immigrants Behind American Dairy | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: The economy and immigration are two of the biggest issues on the minds of Americans, but we rarely get a look behind the scenes to see how these key forces in American life intersect. CBS News Race & Culture and CBS Reports reveal the connection between immigration and food prices by following the journey of the people, both legal and undocumented, bringing America's milk to market.

titles.value: Finding Common Ground: Muslims and Jews Bridging the Gap | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: Los Angeles is home to one of the largest populations of Jews in the world, and one of the largest populations of Muslims in America. For almost two decades, a group there has been trying to build bonds between these two communities, but the attack of Oct. 7, 2023 and its aftermath are putting that mission to the test. CBS Reports and CBS News Race and Culture examine these challenges and explore how the next generation may hold the key to forging paths to unity amid adversity.

titles.value: Ultra Processed: How Food Tech Consumed the American Diet | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: Americans are among the world's biggest consumers of ultra-processed foods, which comprise more than half of an average adults diet and two-thirds of a childs. As technology continues to accelerate innovations in additives, chemicals and food products, U.S. regulators are struggling to keep up. CBS Reports examines why ultra-processed foods have become so pervasive in the American diet, and what filling the gaps in federal regulation can do to ensure Americans are fed and healthy.

titles.value: Advanced Recycling: Does Big Plastic's Idea Work? | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: As America grapples with an escalating plastic crisis, the city of Houston, ExxonMobil and other partners announced a new program that promised to recycle nearly all of the city's plastic waste. However, after two years, the program has yet to fully materialize. Critics argue that the evidence suggests it never will. And yet, the company envisions similar programs in other American cities. CBS Reports and Inside Climate News investigate whether this proposed solution to our plastic recycling crisis is indeed too good to be true.

titles.value: Model Prisons: California's Push for Reform | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: Nearly 95% of people currently in prison will be released back into society, and historically a significant percentage are likely to reoffend. In California, authorities are trying to change that by providing inmates access to education, work and other rehabilitative privileges  programs that have been shown to reduce recidivism and increase public safety. CBS Reports examines a controversial approach some see as being soft on crime, which now may be preventing it.

titles.value: CBS Reports | America Unfiltered: The Voices Behind the Polls

shortDescriptions.value: You've seen the CBS News polls that tell you what voters think about big ideas like democracy and the American Dream. Now CBS Reports takes you behind the polls for unfiltered conversations about how their personal stories shaped their views.

titles.value: King of the County: The Power of Sheriffs | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: A murder plot discussed on tape implicating a sheriff in southeastern Oklahoma triggers a CBS News investigation, uncovering a pattern of abuses that have gone largely unchecked for years. It's a cautionary tale that reveals an unsettling reality for small towns across America: when sheriffs abuse their power, people can die and there's little to hold them accountable.

titles.value: Anything for Love: Inside the Romance Scam Epidemic | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: Romance scammers drain billions of dollars from people seeking love, and their tactics have evolved in sinister ways in the online age. CBS News goes inside this devastating epidemic unfolding largely in secret, following the journey of an Illinois woman seeking answers after her mothers mysterious death.

titles.value: No Place Like Home: People with Disabilities' Fight to Stay Out of Institutions | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: CBS Reports goes to Illinois, which has one of the highest rates of institutionalization in the country, to understand the challenges families face keeping their developmentally disabled loved ones at home.

titles.value: Raising the Stakes: America's Growing Sports Gambling Addiction | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: As more states legalize gambling, online sportsbooks have spent billions courting the next generation of bettors. And now, as mobile apps offer 24/7 access to placing wagers, addiction groups say more young people are seeking help than ever before. CBS Reports explores what experts say is a hidden epidemic lurking behind a sports betting bonanza that's leaving a trail of broken lives.

titles.value: Toxic Fog: The Aftermath in East Palestine, Ohio | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: In February 2023, a quiet community in Ohio was blindsided by disaster when a train derailed and authorities decided to unleash a plume of toxic smoke in an attempt to avoid an explosion. Days later, residents and the media thought the story was over, but in fact it was just beginning. What unfolded in East Palestine is a cautionary tale for every town and city in America.

titles.value: The End of Affirmative Action | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down affirmative action in college admissions, CBS Reports examines the fog of uncertainty for students and administrators who say the decision threatens to unravel decades of progress.

titles.value: The Watchlist: 20 Years of Tracking Suspected Terrorists | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: CBS Reports examines the legacy of the U.S. government's terrorist watchlist, 20 years after its inception. In the years since 9/11, the database has grown exponentially to target an estimated 2 million people, while those who believe they were wrongfully added are struggling to clear their names.

titles.value: A Nation in Transition | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: In the 2023 legislative season, over two-thirds of U.S. states either passed or proposed laws restricting gender-affirming care, and lawmakers are debating policies that directly affect the lives of trans youth. CBS Reports sent three correspondents to three key states of a nation in transition to examine the difficult conversations rippling across the country.

titles.value: Fighting for a Future: America's Migration Reckoning | CBS Reports

shortDescriptions.value: Major cities far from the southern border are struggling to deal with the arrival of record numbers of migrants. In New York City, the right to shelter is being tested  and tensions are rising. CBS Reports examines the crossroads of families fighting for a future, a city struggling to keep up, and a nation in the throes of a migration reckoning.

titles.value: Trump will visit Saudi Arabia in May, White House says

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump is expected in Saudi Arabia in May as part of his first international trip during his second term in the White House. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports.

titles.value: Tanker fire in Louisiana may have started after lightning strike

shortDescriptions.value: A massive fire in Louisiana may have started after a lightning strike from severe weather that swept through the state. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul reports.

titles.value: Should Americans be concerned over Trump's tariffs?

shortDescriptions.value: Americans have questions about the impact of President Trump's upcoming tariffs. Colby Smith, a reporter for The New York Times, joins CBS News with more on the worrying sentiments.

titles.value: How law firms are fighting Trump's executive orders

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump's executive orders targeting big law firms could cause a chilling effect on the American justice system. Bob Van Nest, a trial lawyer and partner at Keker, Van Nest & Peters, joins CBS News with more on how his firm is planning to fight back.

titles.value: Myanmar earthquake rescue efforts continue

shortDescriptions.value: Search and rescue missions continue in Myanmar after a 7.7-magnitude earthquake shook Southeast Asia. Arunoday Mukharji with BBC News, a CBS News partner, has more.

titles.value: Suspected explosion at Detroit apartment complex injures several people

shortDescriptions.value: There is an investigation underway in Detroit, Michigan, after an apparent explosion at an apartment complex. At least 12 people were injured, according to officials. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul reports.

titles.value: Uncertainty over tariffs is driving concerns about recession

shortDescriptions.value: Policy uncertainty is driving worries in the markets that may be increasing predictions about an incoming recession. Bill Watts, a markets editor at MarketWatch, joins CBS News with more.

titles.value: Trump on how many countries will be affected by "Libertation Day" tariffs

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump is previewing his "Liberation Day" tariffs as countries around the world await the economic impact of his proposals. CBS News' Willie James Inman has more on Mr. Trump's comments.

titles.value: Senate awaits ruling on permanent Trump tax cuts

shortDescriptions.value: Senate Republicans are awaiting a decision on a rule to allow permanent tax cuts as part of the new budget plan working its way through Congress. CBS News' Caitlin Huey-Burns reports.

titles.value: Mar 31: CBS News 24/7, 1pm ET

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump's reciprocal tariffs set to kick in this week; Israel issues evacuation of the southern Gaza city of Rafah as its offensive ramps up.

titles.value: Latest news on court cases involving Trump administration's immigration policies

shortDescriptions.value: Several Trump administration immigration policies and prominent deportation cases are tied up in court as the judicial branch weighs the constitutionality of recent moves. CBS News' Jake Rosen reports.

titles.value: Severe storm sweeps through U.S. and takes aim at East next

shortDescriptions.value: At least one death has been reported after a severe storm swept through Indiana and crossed several other states. Parts of the South and the East are expecting severe conditions. CBS News' Skyler Henry reports from Atlanta, Georgia, and meteorologist Jessica Burch has the latest weather forecast.

titles.value: Many Americans are concerned about prices, recent CBS News poll shows

shortDescriptions.value: A recent CBS News poll reflects the worries among Americans as they prepare for potential higher prices that may be ushered by President Trump's tariffs. Isabel Wang, a markets reporter for MarketWatch, joins CBS News with more.

titles.value: Trump says new tariffs will be "kinder" than those imposed by other nations

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump says his new tariffs will be "kinder" than those levied by other nations as a response to his ongoing trade war. CBS News' Weijia Jiang reports.

titles.value: Why Musk is pumping millions into a Wisconsin Supreme Court seat election

shortDescriptions.value: Entrepreneur Elon Musk is pumping millions of dollars into a supreme court seat election in Wisconsin. This comes as the state's highest court declines to intervene in a case against Musk for handing out $1 million checks to Wisconsin voters. CBS News' Fin Gmez reports.

titles.value: Apr 1: CBS News 24/7, 10am ET

shortDescriptions.value: Sen. Cory Booker protests Trump administration policies in all-night speech on Senate floor; Israel ramps up strikes in Gaza amid renewed ceasefire negotiations with Hamas.

titles.value: 4/1: CBS Morning News

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump prepares to unveil reciprocal tariffs; How to tell if an image is AI-generated.

titles.value: 3/31: CBS Evening News Plus

shortDescriptions.value: What to expect in Trump's tariff announcement; Reporter's Notebook: Telling the whole truth about America's history

titles.value: 3/31: America Decides

shortDescriptions.value: Is Trump serious about considering a third term?; Why the Trump administration wants to defund public media

titles.value: Mar 31: CBS News 24/7, 4pm ET

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump's reciprocal tariffs set to kick in this week; National Rally Party leader Marine Le Pen barred from holding office for five years

titles.value: Mar 31: CBS News 24/7, 10am ET

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump to roll out new tariffs on April 2; Elon Musk hands out $1 million checks to Wisconsin voters.

titles.value: 3/31: CBS Mornings Plus

shortDescriptions.value: Widespread storms leave hundreds of thousands without electricity. Also, expert unpacks the $80 million Wisconsin Supreme Court race.

titles.value: 3/31: CBS Morning News

shortDescriptions.value: President Trump looking for ways to serve a third term as president; Final Four set in NCAA men's tournament.

titles.value: 3/30: CBS Weekend News

shortDescriptions.value: Myanmar earthquake death toll tops 1,700; Fighting STDs on Indian reservations

titles.value: 3/30: Face the Nation

shortDescriptions.value: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Major Garrett speaks to UAW president Shawn Fain as the Trump administration deals with upcoming tariffs with the markets sliding up and down and consumer confidence sliding. Plus, Sen. Mark Warner joins to discuss the Trump administration's mistake of its own making  sharing attack plans over an app.

titles.value: 3/30: Sunday Morning

shortDescriptions.value: Hosted by Jane Pauley. In our cover story, Ted Koppel looks at the rise of online sports betting and the dangers of gambling addiction. Plus: Tracy Smith talks with Sir Elton John and Brandi Carlile about their collaboration on a new album; Lee Cowan sits down with Maria Shriver, whose latest book, I Am Maria, is a memoir written in poetry; Norah ODonnell examines the future of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, whose new chairman is President Trump; Mo Rocca goes behind the scenes of the new Broadway musical adaptation of the cult classic Death Becomes Her; and Dr. Jon LaPook explores why some doctors are prescribing the arts.

titles.value: The Dish: Pastries and pastry chefs

shortDescriptions.value: We meet three pastry chefs whose sweet creations are winning over hearts and appetites. We meet a self-taught baker in Baltimore and visit a patisserie bringing a taste of Paris to Brooklyn. Watch these stories and more on "The Dish."
